content: The "Patent Abuse Reduction Act of 2013" may be cited as the short title. It includes pleading requirements. The "Patent Abuse Reduction Act of 2013" includes pleading requirements for patent infringement actions, specifying the information that must be included in the initial complaint, counterclaim, or cross-claim. The "Patent Abuse Reduction Act of 2013" mandates detailed information in the initial complaint for patent infringement actions, including specifics on accused instrumentality, identification of each accused element, and explanation of where each element is found within the accused instrumentality. The "Patent Abuse Reduction Act of 2013" requires detailed information in the initial complaint for patent infringement actions, including specifics on the accused instrumentality, infringement details, and the right to assert each claim. The "Patent Abuse Reduction Act of 2013" mandates detailed information in the initial complaint for patent infringement actions, including the identification of patents and claims, description of the party's business, list of complaints filed, licensing terms for patents, and identification of other patent owners. The "Patent Abuse Reduction Act of 2013" requires detailed information in the initial complaint for patent infringement actions, including identifying patents, owners, assignees, exclusive licensees, parties with legal rights to enforce patents, persons with financial interests in the outcome, and descriptions of agreements or legal bases. The "Patent Abuse Reduction Act of 2013" mandates detailed information in initial complaints for patent infringement actions, including descriptions of agreements or legal bases for financial interests. The "Patent Abuse Reduction Act of 2013" requires detailed information in initial complaints for patent infringement actions, and the Supreme Court will review and amend Form 18 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure to align with these requirements. Additionally, there is a rule of construction to clarify that this section does not change existing laws or rules regarding joinder of interested parties. Section 299 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to allow for the joinder of interested parties in civil actions related to patents. An interested party is defined as a person described in specific sections and does not include attorneys or law firms with a financial interest solely based on providing legal representation. The court must grant a motion by a party defending an infringement in such cases. The court may grant a motion to join an interested party in patent infringement cases if the plaintiff's interest is limited to asserting patent claims in litigation. The court can deny joinder if the interested party cannot be served or if it would affect jurisdiction or venue. SEC. 4. DISCOVERY LIMITS. Chapter 29 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on discovery in patent infringement suits. Discovery is limited until a ruling on claim construction is made, focusing on information necessary for the court to determine the meaning of terms used in the patent claim. The court has the discretion to expand the scope of discovery for timely resolution of actions. The court may permit additional discovery before ruling on a civil action related to patents to ensure timely resolution, especially when motions need to be resolved before construction of terms. The court may allow limited additional discovery in patent-related civil actions to resolve motions before construction of terms. The court may allow limited additional discovery in patent-related civil actions to resolve motions before construction of terms, including evidence related to reduction to practice, technical operation of infringing instrumentality, invalidating prior art, licensing history, revenue from claimed inventions. The court may allow limited additional discovery in patent-related civil actions to resolve motions before construction of terms, including evidence related to ownership, awareness of patent, marking, and exclusion of computer code. In patent-related civil actions, limited additional discovery may be allowed by the court to resolve motions before term construction, including evidence related to ownership, awareness of patent, marking, and exclusion of electronic communication unless good cause is found. Parties must discuss the completion of core documentary evidence discovery in written reports filed under rule 26(f)(2) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. In patent-related civil actions, parties must discuss completion of core documentary evidence discovery, additional discovery under paragraph (3), and issues related to infringement, invalidity, or damages to simplify the case. Each party is responsible for discovery costs in patent-related civil actions. In patent-related civil actions, parties are responsible for producing core documentary evidence at their own cost. Additional discovery can be sought by a party relating to patents if they bear the costs, including attorney's fees. In patent-related civil actions, parties are responsible for producing core documentary evidence at their own cost. Additional discovery can be sought by a party if they pay the anticipated costs or post a sufficient bond. This does not entitle a party to information not otherwise discoverable or require the production of privileged matter. The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure allow courts to limit excessive, irrelevant, or abusive discovery requests and set boundaries on discovery. SEC. 5. COSTS AND EXPENSES. Section 285 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to award reasonable costs and expenses, including attorney's fees, to the prevailing party unless exceptional circumstances exist. The court cannot consider settlements as evidence in determining exceptions. If the non-prevailing party cannot pay, costs and expenses may be recovered from any interested party.
